title: Practice Challenge
description: Apply what you've learned in this interactive coding challenge.
instructions:
Create a simple console application that demonstrates AOT compatibility!

1. Create a record called 'AppInfo' with properties:
   - Name (string)
   - Version (string)
   - StartTime (DateTime)

2. In your main code:
   - Create an AppInfo instance with your app's details
   - Print the app name and version
   - Calculate and print how long since the app started (use Stopwatch)
   - Print whether the process is 64-bit
   - Print the working set memory in MB

3. Add comments indicating which parts are AOT-compatible

Focus on AOT-safe patterns (no reflection, no dynamic code generation).

hints.text: Record types: public record AppInfo(string Name, string Version, DateTime StartTime); - single line definition!
Stopwatch: var sw = Stopwatch.StartNew(); then sw.Stop(); then sw.ElapsedMilliseconds
Environment.Is64BitProcess returns bool. Environment.WorkingSet returns long (bytes).
String interpolation with format: $"{value:F2}" formats as fixed-point with 2 decimals.

commonMistakes.consequence: typeof(T).GetProperties() may not work in AOT! Reflection is limited without special annotations.
commonMistakes.correction: Access properties directly: appInfo.Name, not reflection. AOT needs to know types at compile time.

commonMistakes.consequence: dynamic requires runtime compilation which doesn't exist in AOT. Will throw at runtime!
commonMistakes.correction: Use strong typing. Replace 'dynamic' with concrete types or generics.

commonMistakes.consequence: dotnet publish without -r fails for AOT! Native code is platform-specific.
commonMistakes.correction: Always specify: -r win-x64, -r linux-x64, -r osx-arm64, etc.

commonMistakes.consequence: WorkingSet / (1024 * 1024) uses integer division, losing precision!
commonMistakes.correction: Use 1024.0 * 1024.0 to force floating-point division for accurate MB values.
